comments.commentBody: What game?  It is all commercials.
Other former presidents (and other ex-politicians, cabinet secretaries) receive large sums for speaking and advising and sitting on boards. What was expected of them and what did they do?

Try rugby.  Not only is it safer for the players, (no helmet to helmet hits or  taking a helmet in your kidney from behind) but upon becoming a rugby fan I've found American football unwatchable.  It's simply too slow.

There are a variety of other weapons the B-21 could use, including older cruise missiles and satellite-guided bombs. But I suspect the author supports the B-21 largely because it has a dual role and can be used to deliver conventional weapons. There is wisdom in this. The United States has spent several fortunes on ICBMs and boomers. The money supports deterrence, but that doesn't change the fact that these weapons cost billions of dollars and are never "used."
Not like there's anything else to watch.

Ironically, the professional game of American football has become faster, harder hitting and more athletic . . . YET, more tedious to watch.

1. This season has had an inordinate # of lackluster match ups. Overall team play seems robotic with individual players making mind numbingly, stupid infractions -- holding, off sides & personal fouls -- which kill potential scoring drives.

2. In the NFL's effort to promote a passing offense game (to make it more exciting to watch), the opposite has resulted. The few teams with smart coaching (i.e.. NE Patriots w/ Bill Belichick) have created a offense scheme based on high percentage, short throws to behemoth tight ends. 7-20 yards "dink & dunk" stuff. Further encouraging this are the restraints put on the defensive backs. Pass interference is continually called in NFL games.

Yes, it's a smart way to win . . . plus it saves on your QB . . . but it's a yawn of a game. Seasonal passing yardage, completion % & TD #s have skyrocketed -- yet the "elite" QBs today would not have lasted 8 seasons in the NFL of the 1960s & '70s.

Totally agree that this is a sad diversion tactic, highlighting unimportant infighting at this moment is truly bad journalism. My sole disagreement is that it is distracting from more important leaks and the fact that the leaks are more important than only this.

Wish the newspaper I read had those kind of guts too.
There is no evidence anywhere that the emails are forgeries. It would be out of character for Julian Assange to be so careless.
You  must too young to recall the theft of the Pentagon Papers by Daniel Elsberg (sic) and the subsequent printing in the NYT. Sometimes illegal acts are needed to shine light into dark corners!

Well, if these STOLEN or FAKED emails are genuine in any way, they reflect the very same discussions that take place inside the New York Times, inside any company, entity, foundation, or other organization that frets and worries and screams over anything that could possibly go wrong. This is the sort of stuff that goes on anywhere people worry, argue, and come to eventual consensus. But the press, including even the vaulted New York Times, doesn't mind painting such internal squabbles any way they see fit. And do remember, these are STOKEN or FAKED documents (because the press certainly doesn't know or care). This is rubbish reporting. Worse still, in the shadow of Trump's colossal misdeeds, misogyny, and pathological lies, this is a diversion tactic. The destruction of American society that a Trump Presidency would guarantee is the real focus or should be. And that is what will be decided on November 8th. The very heart and soul of this nation is on the line. Twelve days before that fateful moment arrives is no time for impressionist interpretations of internal arguments in Clinton's camp. I, for one, am highly impressed that her organization hashed this all out in bold, forthright, even downright nasty terms. That's how the best decisions are always made.

Wish the company I work for had those kind of guts.
Perhaps attention to security of confidential communications deserved more emphasis.

Thank you for writing this. I am glad you survived to tell the story.

This is a day in the life... the real life of soldiers and journalists in the modern war zone. This is not "Rah Rah" Support The Troops glamorous: it's grim and ugly, and tedious - because this same routine goes on and on, as does the danger.

Trump says, "I love war" - and his fans love it and cheer. Why? Trump hasn't got a wisp of a clue about any of this! Current evidence leans towards the sad fact that he probably can't find Iraq on a map. We need a President who knows that war is not fun, and is a high risk roulette exercise at best, with the odds against you almost all the time. That is not Trump. We can't even be sure Trump could greet the Fallen on their arrival back home, without making it all about himself, or one of his hotels. He even thinks nuclear war is entirely viable! He is not alone in his war lust. Many GOTP candidates openly mused which country they would go to war with "on day one of my Administration" - and most on the Right saw nothing wrong with it.

It's past time for an article like this to be published again in the NYT. Sadly, this sequence of events leading up to a car bomb has happened so many times before. It's resulted in troops coming home in grey caskets or strapped to gurneys with tubes coming out all over, and a shattered life to rebuild. We need to remember... all of us. This is what our troops face when they go on a Mideast tour. It's why we should cherish them.
Now, that is NEWS, since Bill and Hillary don't receive a salary from the Clinton Foundation. So, there is NO PROFIT for the family, it is a charity, meaning NON-Profit.

Cuz, the Saudis and Qatar have been for MANY MANY YEARS, and that is not the fault of Hillary.

We have been allies with those countries through my entire life.
Bush was... Carter was, Obama has been... Reagan was... Bush 1 was.

Why is that on Hillary?

Look at the Clinton Foundation during the years Hillary was sitting as Secretary of State. The foundation contributed less than 6% to charity and operated as a slush fund for Bill, Chelsea, Huma, Cheryl Mills, Sidney Bloomenthal, and other Clinton friends.

Where's the beef here? The Clinton Foundation is set up to raise funds for charitable purposes. It does. Did the fund donors receive special favors from Hillary Clinton in return? There is no evidence of that in this article. A lot of it is reporting on petty backbiting and name calling. Who cares.
Whoa... bravo! It doesn't get more real than this.

My-tee cuh-lever!  Very fun solve!  I was so tickled as I realized all the down words were legit words in themselves, and thought about how hard that must have been to pull off.  Then I read the Constructor's Notes and was Even More Impressed, in kinda Pooh-speak.  Kudos!
There's an old Italian expression Karen: "Lies make the trains run on time."
Dribble, as in hoops, or drivel?

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
AND we the people feel much calmer when not being told politically embarrassing truths regarding people being paid VERY well out of our paychecks.
The Clinton aides reacted out of the mindset they came out of college with regarding MORALITY. Only in recent years did these co-conspirators learn that the ''m'' word above never even mattered to this most corrupt Presidential candidate in American history.

I'm so tired of Wikileaks and the emails, the gothchas and endless dribble, the hate and this election.
To our next President, our Congress and House of Representatives, its in your hands to heal this country. ' We the People' would like domestic tranquility and the promotion of general Welfare for all..

Yes. That's my one complaint about this story: It's about Bryan Denton, not the other men, and it's my own fault because I know I wouldn't click on a link that stated "Iraqi Soldiers Killed by Car Bomb During Advance on Mosul." Neither would anyone else reading this comment.

Us Americans are such jerks sometimes. But we're still (mostly) right about how to live. Thank goodness I was born in Manhattan and not Mosul.
Bryan Denton is brave and I appreciate this on-the-ground reporting. It is too rare. However, the Iraqi men fighting ISIS are beyond courageous.
Whatever. In the very near future it will be Madam President. Okay?

I watched the war in Vietnam on tv when I was young and became anti-war.
The soldiers kept re-taking the same sites over & over. We left Iraq, it was overrun by isis, and we are now once again trying to re-take territories and drive them out. I know we have to fight isis but I'm afraid in the end we will have learned the same lessons. I admire the journalists & photographers who put their lives on the line to keep us informed.

Seeing this warfare leaves me feeling gratitude to Bryan Denton and the other brave journalists covering this war, as well as to our soldiers and our allies in this fight. So glad Bryan Denton survived. Be safe, Bryan!
This war causes so many thoughts to flood into my head (most of them anger at Bush the Second for fraudulently starting this terrible war) that I feel the two predominant ones are just random, but here goes:
1. Can we really not get a helmet for all of our allied soldiers? I know four-year-olds riding bikes on suburban streets who take more safety precautions. (There must be some explanation for the lack of helmets, but it is hard to imagine that it is sensible.)
2. The U.S. damn well better stand by the Kurds in their struggle for independence because they have been our toughest allies for a long, long time in extremely dirty conflict. We abandoned them under Reagan, and again under Bush the First. It's time we did right by these people and helped them achieve independent nation status so they are not subjected to nationalistic tyranny again! P.S. Let's not let the Turks' demands cause us to forsake the Kurds again. I believe smart diplomacy can make it happen.

Indeed - wars are always directed by a few old men who have power and control over legions of young men, and who remain well away from the actual fighting.  That's why it is so satisfying when these perpetrators of war get their heads put upon pikes.

This is why it's so offensive when politicians complain about "the media." At the same time, it's also offensive when "aggregators" of Internet content steal someone else's work, slap their byline on it, and call themselves "reporters."

Mr. Denton, best of luck.

And for the rest of you, remember that our allies, even if they aren't American news photographers, bleed and suffer just the same. So do our enemies, but we want them to bleed and suffer, and then die.

I am a loyalist but I have read each email and so far they are really just a lot of garbage.  Unless WikiLeaks gets into Trumps campaign emails and publishes them I see them as illegally obtained, Russian garbage

Yes, it remains hard, if not impossible, to understand. Why must anyone, Christian or otherwise, kill non-believers? If this is what your diety seeks, to kill all those who don't believe, it is madness. Please, keep your religion to yourself, impose it not on me.
Also, some have suggested that it would not be so difficult to alter the emails so we cannot judge their somplete accuracy.

Not mentioned in the column, but posted by a reader, China and Japan gave the Philippines a few $billion in 2011. What's the current aid figure? Don't know, but $200 million is less than 1/10 that amount. China is throwing around alot of  money these days, buying influence.

But is she alone in having a shallow campaign? Probably not. Other politician's campaigns are surely just as shallow, they're just so good at the game that they're able to convince voters that they have substance.

I think the bottom line here is that Duterte sees that he's in China's back yard, and is being realistic about that geostrategic fact; plus he can hit up the Chinese for more aid than he's likely to get from the U.S.
As far as getting everybody back into their boxes, that's going to be a rough game indeed. The Chinese especially have no intention of letting themselves be contained, and seek to expand their influence. And I fear that Clinton may feel it necessary to use foreign policy as a horsewhip on the Republican party, i.e. make the case that they are aiding and abetting the Chinese and Russians. A new "Cold War" as it were, with the Democrats playing rally 'round the flag, for a change.
